API¶

This page is an overview of the API used for data analytics by Matur team.

Links

  • Pipeline

  • Azimuthal Integration

  • Containers

  • DB Download

  • Transformers

  • Fourier

  • Fitting Functions

Pipeline¶

class MLPipeline(data_wrangling_steps=None, splitter=<function train_test_split>, preprocessing_steps=None, estimator=None)¶

Bases: object

Builds a modular pipeline for data wrangling, preprocessing, and estimator training.

add_data_wrangling_step(name, transformer, position=None)¶

Adds a data wrangling step to the pipeline.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name of the data wrangling step.

  • transformer (callable) – The transformer function to apply in the step.

  • position (int, optional) – The position to insert the step. If None, adds to the end.

add_preprocessing_step(name, transformer, position=None)¶

Adds a preprocessing step to the pipeline.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name of the preprocessing step.

  • transformer (callable) – The transformer function to apply in the step.

  • position (int, optional) – The position to insert the step. If None, adds to the end.

export_pipeline(wrangle=False, preprocess=True, save_path=None)¶

Exports the full pipeline including wrangling, preprocessing, and estimator steps.

Parameters:

  • wrangle (bool) – Whether to include wrangling steps in the exported pipeline.

  • preprocess (bool) – Whether to include preprocessing steps in the exported pipeline.

  • save_path (str, optional) – The file path to save the exported pipeline. Defaults to None.

Returns:

The full pipeline.

Return type:

Pipeline

export_predictions(data, save_path, wrangle=False, preprocess=True)¶

Exports predictions for the given dataset to a CSV file.

Parameters:

  • data (DataFrame) – The dataset to predict on.

  • save_path (str) – The file path to save the predictions.

  • wrangle (bool) – Whether to apply wrangling steps to the data.

  • preprocess (bool) – Whether to apply preprocessing steps to the data.

infer_y(X, y_column, y_value=None)¶

Infers the y values from the dataset based on a column and an optional filter value.

Parameters:

  • X (DataFrame) – The dataset.

  • y_column (str) – The column containing the target variable.

  • y_value (object, optional) – The value to filter y values by. Defaults to None.

Returns:

The inferred y values.

Return type:

Series

predict(X, wrangle=False, preprocess=True)¶

Predicts outcomes using the trained estimator.

Parameters:

  • X (DataFrame) – The dataset to predict on.

  • wrangle (bool) – Whether to apply wrangling steps to the data.

  • preprocess (bool) – Whether to apply preprocessing steps to the data.

Returns:

The predicted values.

Return type:

Series

predict_proba(X, wrangle=False, preprocess=True)¶

Predicts class probabilities using the trained estimator.

Parameters:

  • X (DataFrame) – The dataset to predict on.

  • wrangle (bool) – Whether to apply wrangling steps to the data.

  • preprocess (bool) – Whether to apply preprocessing steps to the data.

Returns:

The predicted probabilities.

Return type:

ndarray

preprocess(data)¶

Apply the processing steps to the entire dataset.

Parameters:

data (DataFrame) – The dataset to preprocess.

Returns:

The preprocessed dataset.

Return type:

DataFrame

set_estimator(estimator)¶

Sets the estimator for the pipeline.

Parameters:

estimator (object) – The estimator to be used for model training.

set_splitter(splitter)¶

Sets the dataset splitter for the pipeline.

Parameters:

splitter (callable) – The method to use for splitting the dataset.

train(X, y_column, y_value=None, y_data=None, wrangle=True, split=True, preprocess=True, print_flag=True, show_flag=False, min_sensitivity=None, min_specificity=None, **split_args)¶

Execute the full training pipeline, including data wrangling, splitting, preprocessing, fitting, and validation.

Parameters:

  • X (pandas.DataFrame) – The input dataset.

  • y_column (str) – Name of the target variable column.

  • y_value (object, optional) – Target variable value to filter on. Defaults to None.

  • y_data (pandas.Series, optional) – Predefined target values. Defaults to None.

  • wrangle (bool) – If True, apply data wrangling steps. Defaults to True.

  • split (bool) – If True, split the dataset into training and test sets. Defaults to True.

  • preprocess (bool) – If True, apply preprocessing steps. Defaults to True.

  • print_flag (bool) – If True, print validation results. Defaults to True.

  • show_flag (bool) – If True, display the ROC curve. Defaults to False.

  • min_sensitivity (float, optional) – Minimum sensitivity threshold. Defaults to None.

  • min_specificity (float, optional) – Minimum specificity threshold. Defaults to None.

  • split_args (dict) – Additional arguments for the dataset splitter function.

train_estimator(X, y)¶

Trains the estimator using the provided features and target variable.

Parameters:

  • X (DataFrame) – The feature matrix.

  • y (Series) – The target variable.

Returns:

The trained estimator pipeline.

Return type:

Pipeline

Train preprocessor and apply the processing steps to the entire dataset.

Parameters:

data (DataFrame) – The dataset to preprocess.

Returns:

The preprocessed dataset.

Return type:

DataFrame

train_preprocessor(data)¶

Trains the preprocessing pipeline on the dataset.

Parameters:

data (DataFrame) – The dataset to train the preprocessor on.

Returns:

The trained preprocessor pipeline.

Return type:

Pipeline

validate(y_true, y_score, metrics=['accuracy', 'roc_auc'], show_flag=False, print_flag=False, min_sensitivity=None, min_specificity=None)¶

Validate the performance of the trained estimator on test data.

Parameters:

  • y_true (pandas.Series) – The true target values.

  • y_score (numpy.ndarray) – Predicted probabilities for the positive class.

  • metrics (list) – Metrics to compute, e.g., [“accuracy”, “roc_auc”].

  • show_flag (bool) – If True, displays the ROC curve. Defaults to False.

  • print_flag (bool) – If True, prints the validation results. Defaults to False.

  • min_sensitivity (float, optional) – Minimum sensitivity threshold. Defaults to None.

  • min_specificity (float, optional) – Minimum specificity threshold. Defaults to None.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the computed metric results.

Return type:

dict

validate_dataset(data, y_column=None, y_value=None, y_data=None, wrangle=False, preprocess=False, metrics=['accuracy', 'roc_auc'], show_flag=False, print_flag=False, min_sensitivity=None, min_specificity=None)¶

Validate the trained estimator on a dataset using specified metrics.

Parameters:

  • data (pandas.DataFrame) – The dataset for validation.

  • y_column (str, optional) – Name of the target variable column. Defaults to None.

  • y_value (object, optional) – Target variable value to filter on. Defaults to None.

  • y_data (pandas.Series, optional) – Predefined target values. Defaults to None.

  • wrangle (bool) – If True, apply data wrangling steps. Defaults to False.

  • preprocess (bool) – If True, apply preprocessing steps. Defaults to False.

  • metrics (list) – Metrics to compute, e.g., [“accuracy”, “roc_auc”].

  • show_flag (bool) – If True, displays the ROC curve. Defaults to False.

  • print_flag (bool) – If True, prints the validation results. Defaults to False.

  • min_sensitivity (float, optional) – Minimum sensitivity threshold. Defaults to None.

  • min_specificity (float, optional) – Minimum specificity threshold. Defaults to None.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the computed metric results.

Return type:

dict

wrangle(data)¶

Applies data wrangling steps to the entire dataset.

Parameters:

data (DataFrame) – The dataset to apply the wrangling steps to.

Returns:

The wrangled dataset.

Return type:

DataFrame

wrangle_preprocess_transform(data, train=True)¶

Applies both wrangling and preprocessing steps to the dataset.

Parameters:

  • data (DataFrame) – The dataset to transform.

  • train (bool) – Whether to train the preprocessor on the data.

Returns:

The transformed dataset.

Return type:

DataFrame

Azimuthal Integration¶

This file includes functions and classes essential for azimuthal integration

calculate_deviation(row: Series, above_limits=[1.2], below_limits=[0.8], npt=256, mask=None)¶

Calculate deviation of measurements against predefined limits.

Parameters:

  • row (pd.Series) – A pandas Series containing data and configuration for deviation calculation.

  • above_limits (list[float]) – A list of upper threshold multipliers for deviation calculation. Defaults to [1.2].

  • below_limits (list[float]) – A list of lower threshold multipliers for deviation calculation. Defaults to [0.8].

  • npt (int) – Number of points for azimuthal integration. Defaults to 256.

  • mask (np.ndarray or None) – An optional mask to exclude specific data points. Defaults to None.

Returns:

Results containing above and below deviation images, and their respective averages.

Return type:

tuple

calculate_deviation_cake(row: Series, above_limits=[1.2], below_limits=[0.8], npt=256, mask=None)¶

Calculate deviation in the “cake” representation of azimuthal data.

Parameters:

  • row (pd.Series) – A pandas Series containing data and configuration for deviation calculation.

  • above_limits (list[float]) – A list of upper threshold multipliers for deviation calculation. Defaults to [1.2].

  • below_limits (list[float]) – A list of lower threshold multipliers for deviation calculation. Defaults to [0.8].

  • npt (int) – Number of points for azimuthal integration. Defaults to 256.

  • mask (np.ndarray or None) – An optional mask to exclude specific data points. Defaults to None.

Returns:

Results containing above and below deviation “cake” images, reverse transformations and their respective averages.

Return type:

tuple

initialize_azimuthal_integrator_df(pixel_size, center_column, center_row, wavelength, sample_distance_mm)¶

Initializes or gets a cached azimuthal integrator with the given parameters.

Parameters:

  • pixel_size (float) – The size of a pixel on the detector, in meters.

  • center_column (float) – The column index of the center point for integration.

  • center_row (float) – The row index of the center point for integration.

  • wavelength (float) – The wavelength of the incident X-ray beam, in angstroms.

  • sample_distance_mm (float) – The sample-to-detector distance, in millimeters.

Returns:

  • pyFAI.azimuthalIntegrator.AzimuthalIntegrator: An instance of the PyFAI AzimuthalIntegrator.

initialize_azimuthal_integrator_poni_text(ponifile_text)¶

Initializes or gets a cached azimuthal integrator based on ponifile text.

Parameters:

ponifile_text (str) – Text content of the .poni file

Returns:

PyFAI AzimuthalIntegrator instance

Return type:

pyFAI.azimuthalIntegrator.AzimuthalIntegrator

perform_azimuthal_integration(row: Series, column: str, npt=256, mask=None, mode='1D', calibration_mode='dataframe', thres=3, max_iter=5, thickness_adjustment=False, thickness_adjustment_distance=700, calc_cake_stats=False, angles=None)¶

Perform azimuthal integration on a single row of a DataFrame.

Parameters:

  • row (pandas.Series) –

    A row from a pandas DataFrame, expected to contain the following columns:

    • measurement_data (array_like): A 2D array containing the measurement data.

    • center (tuple): A tuple of two floats representing the center coordinates (y, x) for the integration.

    • wavelength (float): The wavelength of the incident X-ray beam, in nanometers.

    • calculated_distance (float): The calculated distance from the sample to the detector, in meters.

    • pixel_size (float): The size of a pixel on the detector, in micrometers.

    • interpolation_q_range (tuple or None, optional): A tuple (q_min, q_max) specifying the range of q values for interpolation, where q is the momentum transfer, in reciprocal nanometers. If not provided, the full q range will be used.

    • azimuthal_range (tuple or None, optional): A tuple (min_deg, max_deg) specifying the range of degrees for integration. Degrees are in a range from -180 to 180.

    OR

    • calibration_measurement_id (int): Integer associated with the ID of a specific calibration, used to name the poni file.

    • measurement_data (array_like): A 2D array containing the measurement data.

    • ponifile (str): A string for poni file usage.

    • interpolation_q_range (tuple or None, optional): A tuple (q_min, q_max) specifying the range of q values for interpolation, where q is the momentum transfer, in reciprocal nanometers. If not provided, the full q range will be used.

    • azimuthal_range (tuple or None, optional): A tuple (min_deg, max_deg) specifying the range of degrees for integration. Degrees are in a range from -180 to 180.

  • npt (int) – Number of points for integration. Defaults to 256.

  • mask (array_like) – Mask array to be applied during integration. 1s are for pixels to be masked, 0s for pixels to be integrated. Defaults to None.

  • mode (str) – Mode of integration. ‘1D’ for 1-dimensional integration and ‘2D’ for 2-dimensional integration. Defaults to ‘1D’.

  • calibration_mode (str) – Mode of calibration. ‘dataframe’ is used when calibration values are columns in the dataframe, ‘poni’ is used when calibration is in a poni file. Defaults to ‘dataframe’.

  • thres (int) – Threshold for sigma clipping. Used only in “sigma_clip” mode. Defaults to 3.

  • max_iter (int) – Maximum number of iterations for sigma clipping. Used only in “sigma_clip” mode. Defaults to 5.

  • calc_cake_stats (bool) – Whether to calculate cake statistics in “2D” mode. Defaults to False.

  • angles (list of tuples or None) – List of angle ranges for integration in “rotating_angles” mode. Defaults to None.

Returns:

  • numpy.ndarray: The array of radial q values (momentum transfer) resulting from the integration.

  • numpy.ndarray: The intensity values resulting from the integration.

  • numpy.ndarray, optional: The array of azimuthal angles (radians) for 2D integration, returned only if mode is ‘2D’.

Containers¶

class Action(value, names=None, *, module=None, qualname=None, type=None, start=1, boundary=None)¶

Bases: Enum

Enum class defining actions that can be taken on data: DELETE or REPLACE.

class Limits(q_min_saxs: float, q_max_saxs: float, q_min_waxs: float, q_max_waxs: float)¶

Bases: object

Data class that defines the SAXS and WAXS q-range limits.

Parameters:

  • q_min_saxs (float) – Minimum q value for SAXS.

  • q_max_saxs (float) – Maximum q value for SAXS.

  • q_min_waxs (float) – Minimum q value for WAXS.

  • q_max_waxs (float) – Maximum q value for WAXS.

class Rule(column_name: str)¶

Bases: object

Data class that defines a basic rule for operations on a specified column.

Parameters:

column_name (str) – The name of the column to apply the rule to.

class RuleQ(column_name: str, q_column_name: str, q_value: float, lower: float = None, upper: float = None, cancer_diagnosis: bool = None)¶

Bases: Rule

Defines a rule that removes entries based on intensity at a specific q value.

Parameters:

  • q_column_name (str) – The name of the column containing q values.

  • q_value (float) – The q value at which the intensity is evaluated.

  • lower (float, optional) – The lower intensity threshold for filtering. If None, no lower threshold.

  • upper (float, optional) – The upper intensity threshold for filtering. If None, no upper threshold.

  • cancer_diagnosis (bool, optional) – Additional boolean flag for filtering based on diagnosis.

class RuleV(action: Action, x: Any = None)¶

Bases: object

Data class that defines a rule to perform an action on a value.

Parameters:

  • action (Action) – The action to take (DELETE or REPLACE).

  • x (Any) – The value used for replacement (if action is REPLACE).

DB Download¶

This file includes functions and classes essential for dealing with EosDX DB for data extraction

class RequestDB(api_key: str, form: Dict[str, str], file_name: str, url: str, unzip_path: str | Path, dataset_name: str = 'data')¶

Bases: object

A dataclass to store essential information for requests to the server.

Parameters:

  • api_key (str) – The API key used for authentication.

  • form (Dict[str, str]) – A dictionary containing form data for the request.

  • file_name (str) – Name of the file where the data will be downloaded.

  • url (str) – The URL of the server. Defaults to a predefined URL.

  • unzip_path (Union[str, Path]) – The path where downloaded files should be unzipped. Defaults to a predefined path.

  • dataset_name (str) – Name to save the dataset as.

download_data(api_key: str, form: Dict[str, str], url: str, file_name: str)¶

Downloads the required data from the EOSDX DB.

Parameters:

  • api_key (str) – The API key as a string.

  • form (Dict[str, str]) –

    JSON-like dictionary representing the request form. See API.md for information.

    Example for cancer tissue data:

    form = {
    'key': 'your-access-key',
    'cancer_tissue': True,
    'measurement_id': '< 3',
    'measurement_date': '2023-04-07'
}

    Example for blind data:

    form = {
    'study': '2',  # 1 for California, 2 for Keele, 3 for mice data
    'key': key,
    'machine': '3', # 1 for Cu, 2 for Mo in California, 3 for Keele
    'manual_distance': '160'
}

  • url (str) –

    The URL of the server.

    Example URLs:

    • URL_DATA = “https://api.eosdx.com/api/getmultiple”

    • URL_BLIND_DATA = “https://api.eosdx.com/api/getblinddata”

  • file_name (str) – Name of the file where the data will be downloaded.

form_df(unzip_path=PosixPath('unzipped_data')) → DataFrame¶

Generates a pandas DataFrame from the data downloaded using the EOSDX API.

Parameters:

unzip_path (Path) – The path where the downloaded data is extracted. Defaults to UNZIP_PATH if not provided.

Returns:

A pandas DataFrame containing the data.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

get_df(request: RequestDB) → DataFrame¶

Makes a request to the database using the provided RequestDB object and returns a pandas DataFrame.

Parameters:

request (RequestDB) – A RequestDB object containing essential information for the request.

Returns:

A pandas DataFrame containing the data retrieved from the database.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

monitor_elapsed_time(start_time, stop_event)¶

Monitors and prints the elapsed time in a separate thread.

Parameters:

  • start_time (float) – The start time of the operation.

  • stop_event (threading.Event) – Event object to signal the thread to stop.

save_df(df, path, dataset_name)¶

Saves the DataFrame as a pickle file.

Parameters:

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – A pandas DataFrame containing the data.

  • path (Path) – The path where the file will be saved. Defaults to UNZIP_PATH if not provided.

  • dataset_name (str) – Filename to save the file as.

unzip_data(file_name: str, unzip_path: str)¶

Unzips data downloaded from the server to the specified folder.

Parameters:

unzip_path (Union[str, Path]) – The path where the data will be extracted. Defaults to UNZIP_PATH if not provided.

Transformers¶

The transformer classes are stored here

class AzimuthalIntegration(max_iter: int = 5, thres: int = 3, column: str = 'measurement_data', faulty_pixels: Tuple[int] = None, mask: List[List[int]] = None, npt: int = 256, integration_mode: str = '1D', calibration_mode: str = 'dataframe', thickness_adjustment: bool = False, thickness_adjustment_distance: float = 700, calc_cake_stats: bool = False, angles: List[Tuple[int]] = None)¶

Bases: TransformerMixin

Transformer class for azimuthal integration to be used in an sklearn pipeline.

Parameters:

  • faulty_pixels (Tuple[int], optional) – A tuple containing the coordinates of faulty pixels. Defaults to None.

  • mask (List[List[int]], optional) – A list of lists containing pixel mask coordinates. Defaults to None.

  • npt (int) – The number of points for azimuthal integration. Defaults to 256.

  • integration_mode (str) – The integration mode, either “1D”, “2D”, or “rotating_angles”. Defaults to “1D”.

  • calibration_mode (str) – Mode of calibration. ‘dataframe’ is used when calibration values are columns in the DataFrame, ‘poni’ is used when calibration is in a poni file. Defaults to ‘dataframe’.

  • calc_cake_stats (bool) – Flag to calculate cake statistics. Defaults to False.

  • max_iter (int) – Maximum number of iterations for processing. Defaults to 5.

  • thres (int) – Threshold value for processing. Defaults to 3.

  • column (str) – Column name containing measurement data. Defaults to ‘measurement_data’.

  • angles (List[Tuple[int]], optional) – List of angle ranges for integration. Defaults to None.

fit(x: DataFrame, y=None)¶

Fit method for the transformer. Since this transformer does not learn from the data, the fit method does not perform any operations.

Parameters:

  • x (pandas.DataFrame) – The data to fit.

  • y – Ignored. Not used, present here for API consistency by convention.

Returns:

Returns the instance itself.

Return type:

object

transform(x: DataFrame) → DataFrame¶

Applies azimuthal integration to each row of the input DataFrame.

Parameters:

x (pandas.DataFrame) – Input DataFrame containing measurement data.

Returns:

DataFrame with additional columns from azimuthal integration results, including ‘q_range’, ‘radial_profile_data’, and other mode-specific columns.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

Raises:

Drops rows with missing calibration data if calibration_mode is ‘poni’.

Fit method is not required for ColumnFlattener, but it is provided for compatibility with sklearn pipelines.

Parameters:

  • X (pd.DataFrame) – Input DataFrame.

  • y (None) – Ignored, exists for compatibility with sklearn pipeline.

Returns:

The fitted transformer.

Return type:

ColumnFlattener

transform(X, y=None)¶

Transforms the specified columns by flattening any arrays and appending the values from each column into a single list for each row.

Parameters:

  • X (pd.DataFrame) – Input DataFrame with columns to flatten.

  • y (None) – Ignored, exists for compatibility with sklearn pipeline.

Returns:

DataFrame where each row is a flattened list of values from the specified columns.

pd.DataFrame

class ColumnNormalizer(column, norm='l1', mode='1D')¶

Bases: TransformerMixin

Transformer class for normalizing arrays in a specific column of a DataFrame to be used in an sklearn pipeline.

Parameters:

  • norm (str) – The type of norm to use for normalization (‘l1’, ‘l2’, or ‘max’). Defaults to ‘l1’.

fit(X, y=None)¶

No fitting required for the Normalizer (stateless), but this method is required for compatibility with sklearn pipelines.

Parameters:

  • X (pd.DataFrame) – Input DataFrame.

  • y (None) – Ignored, exists for compatibility with sklearn pipeline.

Returns:

The fitted transformer.

Return type:

ColumnNormalizer

class CurveFittingTransformer(x_column, y_column, func, p0, bounds=(-inf, inf), param_indices=None, cutoff_ranges=None)¶

Bases: TransformerMixin

A scikit-learn compatible transformer for performing curve fitting on DataFrame columns using a specified function.

This transformer allows for flexible curve fitting across multiple rows of a DataFrame, with customizable function, parameters, and fitting constraints.

Parameters:

  • x_column (str) – Name of the column containing x-values (independent variable) to be used in curve fitting.

  • y_column (str) – Name of the column containing y-values (dependent variable) to be used in curve fitting.

  • func (callable) – The mathematical function to fit. Must accept x as the first argument, followed by parameters to be estimated.

  • p0 (list or array-like) – Initial parameter guesses for the curve fitting algorithm.

  • bounds (tuple, optional) – Parameter boundaries for constrained optimization. Defaults to unconstrained (-∞, +∞) bounds.

  • param_indices (list, optional) – Optional indices to select specific fitted parameters.

  • cutoff_ranges (list of tuples, optional) – Optional ranges to assign high uncertainty to specific data segments during fitting.

fit(X, y=None)¶

Placeholder method for scikit-learn transformer compatibility.

This method does not perform actual fitting but is required for pipeline integration.

Parameters:

  • X (pd.DataFrame) – Input DataFrame containing data to be transformed.

  • y (None, optional) – Target values (ignored).

Returns:

Configured transformer instance.

Return type:

CurveFittingTransformer

transform(X, y=None)¶

Apply curve fitting to each row of the input DataFrame.

Performs curve fitting using the specified function on x and y columns. Adds new columns ‘fit_params’ and ‘fitted_curve’ with fitting results.

Parameters:

  • X (pd.DataFrame) – Input DataFrame containing data for curve fitting.

  • y (None, optional) – Target values (ignored).

Returns:

DataFrame with added fitting results columns.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

Raises:

RuntimeError – If curve fitting fails for any row.

class DataPreparation(columns=['calibration_measurement_id', 'study_name', 'study_id', 'cancer_tissue', 'cancer_diagnosis', 'patient_id', 'wavelength', 'pixel_size', 'calibration_manual_distance', 'calculated_distance', 'measurement_data', 'center', 'ponifile'])¶

Bases: TransformerMixin

Transformer class to prepare a raw DataFrame according to a standard configuration.

Parameters:

columns (List[str]) – Columns definition for DataFrame preparation. Defaults to COLUMNS_DEF.

fit(x: DataFrame, y=None)¶

Fit method for the transformer. Since this transformer does not learn from the data, the fit method does not perform any operations.

Parameters:

  • x (pandas.DataFrame) – The data to fit.

  • y – Ignored. Not used, present here for API consistency by convention.

Returns:

Returns the instance itself.

Return type:

object

transform(df: DataFrame, no_poni=False) → DataFrame¶

Transforms the input DataFrame to adhere to the standard format.

Parameters:

df (pandas.DataFrame) – The raw DataFrame to be transformed.

Returns:

The transformed DataFrame with selected columns.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

class DeviationTransformer(faulty_pixels: Tuple[int] = None, npt=256, above_limits=[1.2], below_limits=[0.8], mode='cake')¶

Bases: TransformerMixin

Transformer class for calculating deviations in an sklearn pipeline.

Parameters:

  • faulty_pixels (Tuple[int], optional) – A tuple containing the coordinates of faulty pixels. Defaults to None.

  • npt (int) – The number of points for integration. Defaults to 256.

  • above_limits (List[float]) – Limits for calculating deviations above a threshold. Defaults to [1.2].

  • below_limits (List[float]) – Limits for calculating deviations below a threshold. Defaults to [0.8].

  • mode (str) – Integration mode, either ‘cake’ or default. Defaults to ‘cake’.

fit(x: DataFrame, y=None)¶

Fit method for the transformer. Since this transformer does not learn from the data, the fit method does not perform any operations.

Parameters:

  • x (pandas.DataFrame) – The data to fit.

  • y – Ignored. Not used, present here for API consistency by convention.

Returns:

Returns the instance itself.

Return type:

object

transform(x: DataFrame) → DataFrame¶

Calculate deviations for each row of the input DataFrame.

Parameters:

x (pandas.DataFrame) – Input DataFrame containing measurement data.

Returns:

DataFrame with additional columns containing deviation results, with different columns based on the selected mode (‘cake’ or default).

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

Raises:

Drops rows with missing calibration data.

class FourierTransform(fourier_mode='', order=15, columns=['radial_profile_data'], remove_beam='false', thresh=1000, padding=0, mask=None, filter_radius=None, features: List[str] | str | None = None)¶

Bases: TransformerMixin

Transformer class to apply Fourier transformation on a specific column of a DataFrame. Includes batch normalization for 2D Fourier transforms.

Fit method for the transformer. For 2D mode with batch normalization, calculates batch statistics from the normalized magnitudes.

  • y – Ignored. Present for API consistency

Returns:

Returns the instance itself

class NormScaler(scalers: Dict[str, StandardScaler] = None, name='Scaler')¶

Bases: TransformerMixin

Transformer for normalization and scaling of a DataFrame.

Parameters:

  • scalers (Dict[str, StandardScaler], optional) – Dictionary of StandardScaler instances for different measurement types. Defaults to None.

  • name (str) – Name of the scaler instance. Defaults to ‘Scaler’.

fit(df: DataFrame, y=None)¶

Fit the scaler to the input DataFrame by computing scaling parameters for SAXS and WAXS measurements.

Parameters:

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – Input DataFrame containing measurement data.

  • y (None, optional) – Target values. Ignored in this transformer.

Returns:

The fitted transformer instance.

Return type:

NormScaler

Note:

Computes and stores separate scalers for SAXS and WAXS measurement types.

transform(df: DataFrame) → DataFrame¶

Transform the input DataFrame by applying L1 normalization and scaling.

Parameters:

df (pandas.DataFrame) – Input DataFrame to be transformed.

Returns:

Transformed DataFrame with normalized and scaled radial profile data.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

Note:

Applies separate scaling for SAXS and WAXS measurement types.

Raises:

Fits the scaler if no scalers are present.

Fourier¶

fourier_custom(curve, order)¶

Applies a custom Fourier transform to extract the Fourier coefficients up to a given order.

Parameters:

  • curve (numpy.ndarray) – The input curve to transform using Fourier series.

  • order (int) – The number of Fourier terms (harmonics) to consider in the expansion.

Returns:

Concatenated list of ‘an’ (cosine) and ‘bn’ (sine) coefficients.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

fourier_fft(curve, order)¶

Applies Fourier transform using FFT (Fast Fourier Transform) and extracts the real and imaginary coefficients.

Parameters:

  • curve (numpy.ndarray) – The input curve to transform using FFT.

  • order (int) – The number of Fourier terms (harmonics) to consider in the expansion.

Returns:

Concatenated list of real and imaginary parts of the Fourier coefficients.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

fourier_fft2(data: ndarray, remove_beam: str = 'false', thresh: float = 700, padding: int = 0, mask: ndarray | None = None, filter_radius: float | None = None, features: List[str] | str | None = None) → Dict[str, ndarray]¶

Perform FFT2 processing with selective feature extraction.

Parameters:

  • data – Input 2D data array

  • remove_beam – Beam removal method (‘false’, ‘real’, ‘fourier’)

  • thresh – Threshold for beam removal

  • padding – Padding around beam for removal

  • filter_radius – Optional radius for frequency domain filtering

  • features – Specific features to extract. Options include: - ‘fft2_shifted’: Shifted FFT - ‘fft2_real’: Real component - ‘fft2_imag’: Imaginary component - ‘fft2_norm_magnitude’: Normalized magnitude - ‘fft2_phase’: Phase - ‘fft2_reconstructed’: Reconstructed image - ‘fft2_vertical_profile’: Vertical frequency profile - ‘fft2_horizontal_profile’: Horizontal frequency profile - ‘fft2_freq_horizontal’: Frequency x-axis - ‘fft2_freq_vertical’: Frequency y-axis - ‘all’: Return all features (default)

Returns:

Dictionary of selected FFT features

slope_removal(y)¶

Removes the slope of a curve by subtracting a linear function that connects the first and last values.

Parameters:

y (numpy.ndarray) – The input curve where slope needs to be removed.

Returns:

The curve with slope removed.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

slope_removal_custom(curve)¶

Removes the slope from a curve by rotating the curve such that the first and last values are set to zero.

Parameters:

curve (numpy.ndarray) – The input curve that requires slope removal.

Returns:

A tuple containing the flattened curve and the transformed x values.

Return type:

tuple (numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray)

Fitting Functions¶

class FittingFunctionProducer(functions: list[FittingFunction])¶

Bases: object

Class to produce fitting functions based on the provided FittingFunction instances.

bounds()¶

Get the bounds for all fitting functions parameters. :return: Bounds for the parameters. :rtype: tuple

initial_guess()¶

Get the initial guess for all fitting functions parameters. :return: Initial guess for the parameters. :rtype: list

produce_function()¶

Calculate the combined function value for all fitting functions.

returned_values()¶

Get the returned values for all fitting functions parameters. :return: List of returned values. :rtype: list

class FittingParameter(value, min_value=-inf, max_value=inf, returned=True)¶

Bases: object

Class to represent a fitting parameter with its properties.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of the parameter.

  • value (float) – Initial value of the parameter.

  • min_value (float) – Minimum value of the parameter.

  • max_value (float) – Maximum value of the parameter.

class GammaDistributionPeak(amp: FittingParameter, position: FittingParameter, k: FittingParameter, theta: FittingParameter)¶

Bases: FittingFunction

Class to represent a Gamma distribution with its properties.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of the distribution function.

  • amp (float) – Amplitude of the distribution.

  • position (float) – Shift (location) parameter.

  • k (float) – Shape parameter (must be positive).

  • theta (float) – Scale parameter (must be positive).

calculate(x, *params)¶

Calculate the Gamma distribution value.

Parameters:

x (numpy.ndarray or float) – Independent variable.

Returns:

Gamma distribution value.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray or float

Utilities¶

Various utility functions used in different parts of codebase

calculate_optimal_threshold(y_true, y_score, min_sensitivity=None, min_specificity=None, print_flag=False)¶

Calculate the optimal threshold for a binary classifier based on the ROC curve, optionally filtering by minimum sensitivity or specificity.

Parameters:

  • y_true (array-like of shape (n_samples,)) – True binary labels.

  • y_score (array-like of shape (n_samples,)) – Target scores, probability estimates of the positive class.

  • min_sensitivity (float, optional) – Minimum required sensitivity for filtering thresholds. Defaults to None.

  • min_specificity (float, optional) – Minimum required specificity for filtering thresholds. Defaults to None.

  • print_flag (bool) – Whether to print the optimal threshold. Defaults to False.

Returns:

A tuple containing true positive rates, false positive rates, the index of the optimal threshold, and the optimal threshold value.

Return type:

Tuple[np.ndarray, np.ndarray, int, float]

combine_h5_to_df(file_paths)¶

Combines multiple HDF5 files into pandas DataFrames for calibration and measurement data.

Parameters:

file_paths (List[str]) – List of paths to the HDF5 files to process.

Returns:

A tuple containing two DataFrames: one with calibration data and one with measurement data.

Return type:

Tuple[pd.DataFrame, pd.DataFrame]

compute_group_statistics(df, label_column, array_column)¶

Computes the mean and standard deviation for groups of arrays in a DataFrame.

Parameters:

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – The input DataFrame containing data for grouping.

  • label_column (str) – The column name containing group labels.

  • array_column (str) – The column name containing 1D arrays.

Returns:

A DataFrame with group labels, means, and standard deviations.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

create_mask(faulty_pixels)¶

Creates a mask array to identify faulty pixels.

Parameters:

faulty_pixels (list of tuples or None) – List of (y, x) coordinates representing faulty pixels, or None.

Returns:

Mask array where 1 indicates a faulty pixel and 0 indicates a good pixel, or None.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray or None

extract_image_data_values(data: ndarray, mask: ndarray) → ndarray¶

Extract image data values using a binary mask where 1 indicates pixels to remove.

Parameters:

  • data (numpy.ndarray) – Input image data array

  • mask (numpy.ndarray) – Binary mask array where 1 indicates pixels to remove

Returns:

Filtered image data with masked values removed

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

Raises:

ValueError – If data and mask shapes do not match

generate_poni_from_text(ponifile_text)¶

Generates a temporary .poni file from the provided ponifile text.

Parameters:

ponifile_text (str) – Text content of the .poni file

Returns:

Path to the temporary .poni file

Return type:

str

generate_roc_based_metrics(y_true, y_score, show_flag=True, min_sensitivity=None, min_specificity=None)¶

Generate ROC-based metrics including sensitivity, specificity, precision, and balanced accuracy, and optionally display the ROC curve.

Parameters:

  • y_true (array-like of shape (n_samples,)) – True binary labels.

  • y_score (array-like of shape (n_samples,)) – Target scores, probability estimates of the positive class.

  • show_flag (bool) – Whether to display the ROC curve. Defaults to True.

  • min_sensitivity (float, optional) – Minimum required sensitivity for filtering thresholds. Defaults to None.

  • min_specificity (float, optional) – Minimum required specificity for filtering thresholds. Defaults to None.

Returns:

A tuple containing optimal sensitivity, optimal specificity, optimal precision, and balanced accuracy (all in percentages).

Return type:

Tuple[float, float, float, float]

get_angle_span(start, end)¶

Calculate the angular span between two angles, handling wraparound across the -180/180 degree boundary.

Parameters:

  • start (float) – Starting angle in degrees.

  • end (float) – Ending angle in degrees.

Returns:

The total angular span between the two angles.

Return type:

float

get_center(data: ndarray, threshold=3.0) → Tuple[float]¶

Determines the center of the beam in SAXS data.

Parameters:

  • data (np.ndarray) – The input SAXS data.

  • threshold (float, optional) – The threshold factor for identifying the center of the beam. Defaults to 3.0 times the average value of the input data.

Returns:

The coordinates of the center of the beam in the input data. If no center is found, returns (np.NaN, np.NaN).

Return type:

tuple

h5_to_df(file_path)¶

Converts an HDF5 file into two pandas DataFrames containing calibration and measurement data.

Parameters:

file_path (str) – Path to the HDF5 file to process.

Returns:

A tuple containing two DataFrames: one with calibration data and one with measurement data.

Return type:

Tuple[pd.DataFrame, pd.DataFrame]

is_all_none(array)¶

Checks if all elements in the input array are None.

Parameters:

array (iterable) – Input array or iterable.

Returns:

True if all elements are None, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

is_nan_pair(pair)¶

Checks if the input is a tuple of two NaN values.

Parameters:

x (tuple or any) – Input to check.

Returns:

True if the input is a tuple of two NaN values, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

mask_beam_center(image: ndarray, thresh: float, padding: int = 0)¶

Isolates and removes a central beam from an image based on a threshold value.

Parameters:

  • image (np.ndarray) – Input image to process for beam removal.

  • thresh (float) – Threshold value to identify the beam region. Pixels above this value are considered part of the beam.

  • padding (int, optional) – Additional padding around the detected beam region in pixels. Defaults to 0.

  • return_coords (bool, optional) – If True, returns the beam coordinates along with the isolated beam image. Defaults to False.

Returns:

If return_coords is False, returns only the isolated beam image. If return_coords is True, returns a tuple containing the isolated beam image and a dictionary of beam coordinates and measurements.

Return type:

Union[np.ndarray, Tuple[np.ndarray, dict]]

perform_weighted_integration(data, ai_cached, range_info, npt, interpolation_q_range, mask=None)¶

Perform integration for angular ranges with proper weighting, handling potential range splits.

Parameters:

  • data (numpy.ndarray) – Input data for integration.

  • ai_cached (pyFAI.AzimuthalIntegrator) – Azimuthal integrator instance.

  • range_info (Dict[str, Union[List[Tuple[float, float]], List[float], float, bool]]) – Dictionary containing processed ranges and weights.

  • npt (int) – Number of points for integration.

  • interpolation_q_range (Tuple[float, float]) – Q range for interpolation.

  • mask (numpy.ndarray, optional) – Optional mask array for integration.

Returns:

A tuple containing (radial, intensity, sigma, std) for the integrated range.

Return type:

Tuple[numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray]

plot_group_statistics(df, label_column, array_column, selected_labels=None)¶

Computes and visualizes group statistics (mean and standard deviation) for arrays within a DataFrame.

Parameters:

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – The input DataFrame containing the raw data.

  • label_column (str) – The column name containing group labels.

  • array_column (str) – The column name containing 1D arrays.

  • selected_labels (list or None) – Labels of the groups to plot. If None, all groups are plotted.

prep(df)¶

Prepare dataframe to RF learning or other models. It uses SCALED_DATA and age of the patient’s measurement.

prepare_angular_ranges(start_angle, end_angle)¶

Prepare angular ranges for integration by validating and processing the angles.

Parameters:

  • start_angle (float) – Starting angle in degrees.

  • end_angle (float) – Ending angle in degrees.

Returns:

A dictionary containing processed integration range information.

Return type:

Dict[str, Union[List[Tuple[float, float]], List[float], float, bool]]

Raises:

ValueError – If input angles are outside the valid -180 to 180 degrees range.

process_angular_ranges(angles)¶

Process angular ranges to handle the -180/180 boundary crossing.

Parameters:

angles (List[Tuple[float, float]]) – A list of tuples containing start and end angles for angular ranges.

Returns:

A list of processed angle ranges accounting for boundary crossings.

Return type:

List[Tuple[float, float]]

unpack_rotating_angles_results(results)¶

Unpack the results from the rotating_angles_analysis function.

Parameters:

results (Tuple[List[Tuple[Tuple[float, float], numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray]], float, float, float]) – A tuple containing results from angular analysis.

Returns:

A dictionary with integration results for various angle ranges and calculated parameters.

Return type:

Dict[str, Union[numpy.ndarray, float]]
